column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Keep an Astronomy Observing Log
#Text=From the time humans have observed the night sky , they have kept records of their observations in various forms : stone , clay tablets , papyrus , parchment , tapestries , and paper .

#Text=These observation logs have led to scientific discoveries , such as Edmond Halley 's discovery that comets are solar system objects with their own orbits ; and cultural practices , such as the 12-year cycle of the Chinese zodiac , inspired in part by the orbital period of the planet Jupiter .

#Text=Keeping a log of your astronomical observations can help you distinguish objects , much as Charles Messier 's catalog helped him distinguish nebulae , star clusters , and galaxies from the comets that interested him , and provide a written record you can use to corroborate or refute weather forecasts and to recall memorable observations , such as meteor showers and auroras .
#Text=Following our steps and suggestions on how to keep an astronomy observing log of your own .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Choose a record keeping medium that works for you .
#Text=You can keep an observing log either on paper or on computer .
#Text=A paper log is easier to take into the field with you than is a laptop computer , although you may find it easier to keep records on a computer than in printed form .

#Text=Computer-based astronomy record keeping programs offer the options of pre-printed log forms and the ability to generate reports , as well as an astronomical database that can help you identify objects and the ability to search your own records to track the positions of planets and comets over time .
#Text=You may want to use several methods , such as a small notebook you carry into the field on which you make notes , which you transcribe to either a larger notebook or binder or onto a computer .
#Text=Some amateur astronomers like to include sketches with their notes .
#Text=If you 're one of them , you 'll need to have a hard surface under your note-taking paper , such as a small clipboard .
#Text=Several websites offer pre-printed astronomy log forms you can use to record your observations on .
#Text=One such site is that run by the American Association of Amateur Astronomers ( http://www.astromax.org/aa02801.htm )
#Text=Record your observations in your astronomy log as soon as you can .
#Text=The sooner you can commit your observation to print or computer , the more accurate your records will be-�not to mention that you may forget to do so entirely if you wait too long .
#Text=This is where taking a simple notepad into the field with you may help .
#Text=Record all the information appropriate to your observation .
#Text=This may include some or all of the following :
#Text=The day and date of your observation session .

#Text=You can record the date in either American format ( month , day , year ) or European/military format ( day , month , year ) , although you may want to write out or use the abbreviation for the month name to avoid confusion on the part of others who may read your observing log .
#Text=The times your observing session began and ended .
#Text=If your observing log includes sketches , include the times those sketches were made .
#Text=Time should be expressed in Universal ( Greenwich Mean ) Time , or your local time , with the mention of whether it was Standard or Daylight Time .

#Text=Your observation location , preferably including your latitude and longitude , but at least the specific area you were conducting your observations in ( city , state , backyard , field , park , etc. ) .
#Text=What kind of telescope you were using ( refractor/reflector � Newtonian , Dobsonian ) , its focal length , eyepiece , magnification , apparent field of view , and any notes on its performance .
#Text=If you use a lens filter , note how images compare with and without the filter .
#Text=What you were observing , including a detailed physical description and/or a sketch .
#Text=Include an estimate of the object 's size based on the angular field of view of your telescope 's eyepiece .
#Text=If the object is a comet , name the constellation the comet appears in and the constellations you searched to find it .
#Text=If the object is a star cluster , include a count of how many stars you can see .
#Text=If the object is a nebula or galaxy , include a description of how concentrated the stars or glowing gases are .
#Text=The amount of moonlight , which can affect how well you can see dimmer stars .

#Text=You can also include an estimate of the apparent magnitude of the dimmest stars you can see directly overhead ( transparency ) and the approximate arc-second diameter of star images ( seeing ) .
#Text=The local weather conditions , including the percentage of cloud cover , and any mist , fog , or haze .
#Text=You can also include non-astronomical observations such as the presence of wildlife or sources of light or other pollution that hamper your ability to see the sky .
#Text=If you 're sharing your observing session with other amateur astronomers , you may want to include their names and notes on their equipment for posterity .
#Text=You can also include personal thoughts .
#Text=Tips
#Text=You may want to develop a code for recording your observations , such as " CH " to indicate you were hunting for comets during an observing session .
#Text=If you do , include a translation key for anyone else who might read your records .
#Text=Consider using a headband or neckband light when doing your astronomical observations so that you have both hands free to write notes or make a sketch in your observing log .
#Text=You can place a red cellophane filter over the lens , and there are headband lights available with switch controls to display either a red or a white light .

#Text=In addition to providing a source of freeware astronomy observing log programs , the Internet also features sites where you can post your astronomical observations for other astronomers to share .
#Text=Some , such as AstronomyLog.com let you post your observations for free and , for a fee , will help you track your progress in whatever observing program you 're taking part in .
#Text=Consider taking part in an observing program .
#Text=Local astronomy clubs and national organizations such as the American Association of
#Text=Amateur Astronomers have observing programs for amateur astronomers ranging from the novice to the advanced level , the best known being to observe all 104 objects in the Messier catalog .

#Text=Taking part in such a program may motivate you to keep your observing log regularly , and when you complete the program , the sponsoring organization will present you with a certificate of achievement .
#Text=Things You 'll Need
#Text=Pen
#Text=Pencil
#Text=Notebook
